    <main role=“main” aria-labelledby=“class-Patterns::Observer”>

    <h1 id="class-Patterns::Observer" class="class">
  class Patterns::Observer
</h1>

<section class="description">

    <p><a href=“Observer.html”>Observer</a> -&gt; <a href=“../Object.html”>Object</a></p>

    <p>An <a href=“Observer.html”>Observer</a> class that receives notifications about events from subjects it is observing Ruby has an <a href=“Observer.html”>Observer</a> module built in to the language, but we will build one to demonstrate how it works and to give it flexibility that we want for this application This implementation can be inherited or used by itself. For example, it could be an <a href=“Admin.html”>Admin</a> class watching a <a href=“User.html”>User</a> class, or it could just be a class called UserObserver. We would simply add this class to whatever subject list we want to observe</p>

    </section>
<section id="5Buntitled-5D" class="documentation-section">

  <section class="attribute-method-details" class="method-section">
    <header>
      <h3>Attributes</h3>
    </header>

    <div id="attribute-i-last_event" class="method-detail">
      <div class="method-heading attribute-method-heading">
        <span class="method-name">last_event</span><span
          class="attribute-access-type">[R]</span>
      </div>

      <div class="method-description">

      <ul><li>

    <p>+@last_notification+ - The last notification this observer received</p> </li><li> <p>+@last_event+ - The last event this observer received</p> </li></ul>

      </div>
</div>
<div id="attribute-i-last_notification" class="method-detail">
  <div class="method-heading attribute-method-heading">
    <span class="method-name">last_notification</span><span
      class="attribute-access-type">[R]</span>
  </div>

  <div class="method-description">

  <ul><li>

    <p>+@last_notification+ - The last notification this observer received</p> </li><li> <p>+@last_event+ - The last event this observer received</p> </li></ul>

        </div>
  </div>
</section>

        class="method-args">()</span>

      <span class="method-click-advice">click to toggle source</span>

    </div>

    <div class="method-description">

      <p>Initializes the observer class</p>

    <p>Examples</p>

    <pre class=“ruby”>=<span class=“ruby-operator”>&gt;</span> <span class=“ruby-identifier”>observer</span> = <span class=“ruby-constant”>Observer</span>.<span class=“ruby-identifier”>new</span> </pre>

    <div class="method-source-code" id="new-source">
  <pre><span class="ruby-comment"># File app/models/observer/observer.rb, line 20</span>

    <span class=“ruby-keyword”>def</span> <span class=“ruby-identifier”>initialize</span>

    <span class="ruby-ivar">@last_notification</span> = <span class="ruby-string">&#39;No notifications received&#39;</span>
<span class="ruby-ivar">@last_event</span> = <span class="ruby-string">&#39;No events received&#39;</span>

    <span class=“ruby-keyword”>end</span></pre>

 <section id="public-instance-5Buntitled-5D-method-details" class="method-section">
   <header>
     <h3>Public Instance Methods</h3>
   </header>

  <div id="method-i-on_notify" class="method-detail ">

    <div class="method-heading">
      <span class="method-name">on_notify</span><span
        class="method-args">(notification, event)</span>

      <span class="method-click-advice">click to toggle source</span>

    </div>

    <div class="method-description">

      <p>Is called when this function is invoked by a subject</p>

    <p>Note: in a real implementation, the event would likely be a complete object or hash, and would contain much more useful information</p> <ul><li> <p>notification - The notification received from the subclass</p> </li><li> <p>event - The event received from the subclass</p> </li></ul>

    <p>Examples</p>

    <pre class=“ruby”>=<span class=“ruby-operator”>&gt;</span> <span class=“ruby-keyword”>def</span> <span class=“ruby-identifier”>notify</span>(<span class=“ruby-identifier”>notification</span>, <span class=“ruby-identifier”>event</span>)

    <span class=“ruby-operator”>&gt;</span> <span class=“ruby-ivar”>@observers</span>.<span class=“ruby-identifier”>each</span> <span class=“ruby-keyword”>do</span> <span class=“ruby-operator”>|</span><span class=“ruby-identifier”>observer</span><span class=“ruby-operator”>|</span>¶ ↑

    <span class=“ruby-operator”>&gt;</span> <span class=“ruby-identifier”>observer</span>.<span class=“ruby-identifier”>on_notify</span>(<span class=“ruby-identifier”>notification</span>, <span class=“ruby-identifier”>event</span>)¶ ↑

    <span class=“ruby-operator”>&gt;</span> <span class=“ruby-keyword”>end</span>¶ ↑

    <span class=“ruby-operator”>&gt;</span> <span class=“ruby-keyword”>end</span>¶ ↑

    </pre>

    <div class="method-source-code" id="on_notify-source">
  <pre><span class="ruby-comment"># File app/models/observer/observer.rb, line 39</span>

    <span class=“ruby-keyword”>def</span> <span class=“ruby-identifier”>on_notify</span>(<span class=“ruby-identifier”>notification</span>, <span class=“ruby-identifier”>event</span>)

    <span class="ruby-ivar">@last_notification</span> = <span class="ruby-identifier">notification</span>
<span class="ruby-ivar">@last_event</span> = <span class="ruby-identifier">event</span>
<span class="ruby-identifier">puts</span> <span class="ruby-node">&quot;Notification: #{notification}, Event: #{event}&quot;</span>

    <span class=“ruby-keyword”>end</span></pre>

            </div>
      </div>

    </div>

  </section>
